sources.title: Hook, Line and Sinker (1930)
sources.description: I've been researching newly public domain films from 1929 and earlier, so I'm uploading the best possible copies that I can find. The third film for comedy duo Wheeler and Woolsey, this film followed insurance salesmen help an attractive woman to fix her run down hotel. Unfortunately, some local gangsters wanted it to stay in ruins. This film was one of the biggest box office hits for RKO studios in 1930, though critically the film doesn't seem to have made much of an impact.

sources.title: Hook Line and Sinker (1930)
sources.description: Two fast-talking insurance salesmen meet Mary, who is running away from her wealthy mother, and they agree to help her run a hotel that she owns. When they find out that the hotel is run down and nearly abandoned, they launch a phony PR campaign that presents the hotel as a resort favored by the rich. Their advertising succeeds too well, and many complications soon arise. Watch on RetroFlix:Â  https://retroflix.org/hook-line-and-sinker-1930/

When they find out that the hotel is run down and nearly abandoned, they launch a phony PR campaign that presents the hotel as a resort favored by the rich. sources.title: Hook Line and Sinker (1930) WHEELER & WOOSLEY
sources.description:
Stars: Bert Wheeler, Robert Woolsey, Dorothy Lee
Director: Edward F. Cline

In this Pre-Code comedy, two fast-talking salesman launch a PR campaign to help a runaway heiress raise money for a dilapidated hotel.

sources.title: Hook Line and Sinker (1930) Comedy, Romance, Pre Code Film
sources.description:
Two fast-talking insurance salesmen meet Mary, who is running away from her wealthy mother, and they agree to help her run a hotel that she owns, and turn it into a social hub ripe for crooks.
 
Director: Edward F. Cline 
Writers: Tim Whelan, Ralph Spence
Stars: Bert Wheeler, Robert Woolsey, Dorothy Lee
Genres: Classics, Comedy, Romance, Pre Code
Budget: $287,000

metadata.Plot: Two fast-talking insurance salesmen meet Mary, who is running away from her wealthy mother, and they agree to help her run a hotel that she owns. When they find out that the hotel is run down and nearly abandoned, they launch a phony PR campaign that presents the hotel as a resort favored by the rich. Their advertising succeeds too well, and many complications soon arise.
